titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alexander Stewart Webb Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Manuscripts and Archives Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:08

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence and papers of Alexander Stewart Webb which detail his personal, military, and academic activities. Webb's military service at Fort Pickens, Florida; as a member of the Army of the Potomac, and with General George Meade during the Civil War is documented, as is his tenure as president of the College of the City of New York.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Alexander Stewart Webb Papers. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of members of the Webb family including Mrs. Eliza Osgood Webb, Anna R. Alexandre, and Mrs. Frederic Schenck, 1936-1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Alexander Stewart Webb Collection consists of five boxes of correspondence and four boxes of printed and written material dealing with the public and private life of Alexander Stewart Webb (1835-1911). The span of the collection 1818 to 1930. The early letters are of his mother and other relatives and the later letters concerning him are Written friends to Webb's son and daughters. The bulk of the collection is the letters of Webb during the Civil War and later as President of the College of the City of New York.

The wartime letters of Alexander Stewart Webb to his father, wife, and sister cover Webb's activities, impressions, and thoughts as an officer at Port Pickens, later in the Amy of the Potomac, and ultimately to serving under General Meade in the final decisive battles of the war. Webb was very active the Peninsula campaign, about which he later wrote a book. He played an outstanding role in the battles at Chancellors ville and Gettysburg, in the letter of rich displayed "distinguished personal gallantry" for which he was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor.

Having been seriously wounded at Spotsylvania, Webb was reassigned to teaching at West Point. He resigned, to accept the presidency of the College of the City of New York in 1869 when assigned to field duty in the West. He was an active administrator in this post and was highly regarded by both students and faculty; his tenure saw a great rise in the prestige and reputation of City College.

During the 1870's, 1880's and 1890's, much of the correspondence deals with the attempt to have Webb's name placed on the U.S. Army officer's reserve list. The bill for this purpose passed either the House or Senate at various times, but it was never passed by both and enacted. Another main topic of the correspondence is the disagreement between two factions over General Meade's conduct at the Battle of Gettysburg. General Webb was one of the leading spokesmen of the pro-Meade group opposing the anti-Meade group led primarily by Generals Butterfield and Doubleday. The conflict reached its height in 1890 at the occasion of the visit of the Count of Paris to the United States.
Webb served as head of City College until his retirement in 1902. He remained active in the civic duties in New York until his death in 1911.

The collection consists of 9 manuscript boxes, one folio, and one folio case containing approximately 4,500 items, donated by various members of the Webb family, including Mrs. Eliza Osgood Webb, Miss Anna R. Alexandre, and Mrs. J. Frederic Schenck, 1936-1964.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research; due to the nature of the material, box 12 requires staff supervision.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Alexander S. Webb: joined U.S. Army in 1855; served in Minnesota and Florida, and in 1857 became professor of mathematics at West Point; served in Civil War, attaining rank of major-general, and retiring in 1866; returned to teaching at West Point; left the army in 1870; in 1869 became president of College of the City of New York.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.physdesc: 4.5 linear feet (9 boxes, 1 folio, 1 folio case)

did.unittitle: Printed matter re court martial, appeal, summary of case, and biographical sketch
Typescripts and manuscript re the battle of Malvern Hill and the character of Porter
"Battle of Gettysburg and Personal Recollections of that Battle" by Colonel Fred. Fuger: typescript
Manuscripts, printed matter, and clippings re Meade at Gettysburg
Biographical sketch of Maj. Gen. Henry W. Slocum (1826-1894): typescript
Reproduction of painting with caption "A view between the opposing lines at a critical point of the battle"
Synopsis of testimony re the location of monument of the 72nd Regt. Pa. Volunteers on Gettysburg Battlefield: typescript
"Sketch of 2nd Manassas, August 29th 1862": annotated printed map
"Why does not the Army of the Potomac Move???": cartoon
"A Recollection" [of Chancellorsville] by Wm. C. Reiff: typescript
Writings about other Webb family members
Reproductions of drawings by Alexander S. Webb
Storage cases for memorabilia (Eye glass case, etc.)
"Sketch Exhibiting the Approach to Richmond from Pamunkey River..." (printed, annotated)
"Extract of Military Map of N.E. Virginia" (printed, 2 copies)
"Central Virginia Showing Lieut. Genl. U.S. Grant's Campaign" (printed)
"Topographical Map of the Vicksburg National Military Park" (printed)
"Map of the Battle Field of Gettysburg" (printed)
"Cotton Map No. 2: Battle-Field of Five Forks" (printed, 3 copies)
"Map Showing Route of Marches of the Army of Genl. W.T. Sherman ..." (printed)
Fragment of map of Yorktown area (printed, annotated)
Unidentified area near Malvern Hill (printed, annotated)
Unidentified area near Berkely Landing on the James River (printed)
Unidentified area (manuscript sketch indicating troop locations)
Memorabilia of Bvt Maj Gen Alexander S. Webb

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Due to the physical nature of the material in box 12, staff supervision is required.

odd.head: General
odd.p: replica of the bronze tablet presented to the College of the City of New York by its officers to commemorate Gen Webb's presidency of that institution 1869-1902

odd.head: General
odd.p: a piece of the original ribbon given by Lafayette to the Society of the Cincinnati when it was first formed shortly after the American Revolutionary War. This ribbon was given to Gen Webb.
